replies.msg:
You are still pretty young and, as an undergraduate, you should have plenty of time to learn English.

I think the best way is to read newspaper, and check the meaning of any unknown vocabulary immediately with the online dictionary, and then write them down for revision.

Repeat this tedious but useful process for months. In the end, while you may forget half of the vocabularies, the remaining half can be seen as a pretty fruitful result.

我以前中學係咁學返嚟

每晚睇一節英文新聞，咩台都唔緊要，最緊要有英文字幕。 係果節新聞嚟drop 低你唔識嘅生字。 之後查字典
記得抄低佢嘅唔同form: noun verb 果d 咁
最重要係唔好淨係簡一個意思，抄低佢嘅幾個唔同意思。 最好睇埋例句睇人地點用

呢個可以增加你嘅vocab. 多vocab 自然你睇書會易睇d

之後listening/speaking/點用英文 我主要係打機/睇英文小說 學返嚟
果陣打機一定會開英文subtitle 之後打得多睇得多你會慢慢聽到佢講乜，同埋有時你講英文都會用返佢用嘅字句。
個人覺得打機會比睇劇有用d. 我覺得打機果d 英文都係偏簡單，一開始睇劇可能會好多俚語呀口語或者當地人先明嘅terms. 但game 可能佢面向全世界所以易明d 呱我估

睇英文書都好大幫助， 搵d 你鐘意嘅書睇，一定會有d 翻譯小說你睇過鐘意睇嘅，去圖書館借返英文版嚟睇，有時你唔明d 字都唔一定要查字典， 軍返上文下理估返個字嘅意思。 如果想學果個字就先估後查咁會更加好

利申：英文唔係話考得好，AL 得個D ，但起碼而家返工成日對鬼佬要講英文，report / document 要英文都完全冇難度。

語文呢d 野真係要日睇夜睇，狂用先會好，加油

you may take a look to see if wordreference.com will help, or you can buy/ borrow some grammar books which are published by relevant authorities. The latter is preferred because it can guarantee what you are going to learn is generally considered as correct in the eyes of many examiners.

quote.msg: But usually you will find dictionaries explaining relatively simple words with more complicated ones.

when there are words that you do not know in a definition, just go to check the meanings of those words, then come back and read the definition again. This is surely troublesome but if you will do it scrupulously, the words that you learn in the end will be multiplied.

There exists no end to this process. In the course of doing so unfortunately but inevitably quite a number of non-native speakers will only find themselves flooded with loads of difficult words that they cannot by any means comprehend.

I am not to deny the merits of your suggestions, but yours is more suitable for people who have a sound English foundation, while looking up chinese dictionaries is apparently (and in fact) more appropriate for beginners.

replies.msg:
You have a point, dude. Using eng-chin dictionary is definitely a better idea for beginners.

我當年係一個完全唔識英文既人 最少去到大學最要求

我做左兩件事

第一樣係每日睇英文報紙頭版一篇
第二樣 作1000字每星期
第三樣 見到唔識既字 就查 一開始用中英字典 慢慢用英英字典

學習過程係有幾個層次

一開始一定最痛苦 因為你識既字唔夠 導致你不能自學 自通

慢慢睇多左 你就可以棄字典

但其實 過左大學幾年 同一直保持睇英文既習慣 就發現左 香港中小英文學習方式係好畸型

學習次序應該係 聽 講 讀寫

聽講係一對
讀寫係一對

有話睇劇學英文 我係認同既 但唔準有subtitles 要自己心入面默到幾多字幕先係叫學習

Eg all of us 睇你會識一隻隻字 但聽鬼老讀你就企係度 聽都有技巧

讀 你要知句子結構 字係點解 字詞既特性

Noun verb adj adv

Countable uncountable 等等

慢慢自己建構句子 睇用法 咬文嚼字

久而久之你英文會好 分分鐘寫得比鬼好

我覺得香港人英文廢係日常生活 但formal letter寫得仲好

1. Select a vocab that can help you express your opinions. Then google that word and see how native speakers use and put it in a sentence, like from their conversation on forum, news articles, blogs and comments that English speaker makes on it.

2. Read more. Cliche to say but old fashioned way always works. Check out the sentence structure and underline the phrase that you find it useful in numerous contexts, like those phrases linking words together (as long as, given that, consequently, there is no doubt that, stemmed from, not to mention that). Plus, you can build a wide range of vocabulary along by acquiring vocab that widely and commonly used in English speaking country through reading, which makes you sound more British/ American (like a local).

3. Dont complicate things, just grab words and phrases that Brits/ American speak or write, use them to voice your opinions in a clear, straightforward way.

P.S. My English sucks too, not too proud to say I got 7 out of 9 in ielts test but um, it’s the way I survive in English test as well as living abroad. Hope this piece of advice will be of use

quote.msg:
1. Select a vocab that can help you express your opinions. Then google that word and see how native speakers use and put it in a sentence, like from their conversation on forum, news articles, blogs and comments that English speaker makes on it.

2. Read more. Cliche to say but old fashioned way always works. Check out the sentence structure and underline the phrase that you find it useful in numerous contexts, like those phrases linking words together (as long as, given that, consequently, there is no doubt that, stemmed from, not to mention that). Plus, you can build a wide range of vocabulary along by acquiring vocab that widely and commonly used in English speaking country through reading, which makes you sound more British/ American (like a local).

3. Dont complicate things, just grab words and phrases that Brits/ American speak or write, use them to voice your opinions in a clear, straightforward way.

P.S. My English sucks too, not too proud to say I got 7 out of 9 in ielts test but um, it’s the way I survive in English test as well as living abroad. Hope this piece of advice will be of use

You are still pretty young and, as an undergraduate, you should have plenty of time to learn English.

I think the best way is to read newspaper, and check the meaning of any unknown vocabulary immediately with the online dictionary, and then write them down for revision.

Repeat this tedious but useful process for months. In the end, while you may forget half of the vocabularies, the remaining half can be seen as a pretty fruitful result.
instead of writing the translation of the word, try to make a sentence out of the unknown word.  Application is usually the most efficient way to learn a language.

You need to link the vocab items up. Do not treat every word you know as if they were isolated. Try to use a thesaurus to build up the connection between words.

Also, every word comes with a context and a particular usage. Do not just remember the meaning of the word. Try to remember its usage.

Read something you really like or want to learn.

quote.msg: I will try to write a passage for this IELTS past paper probably on tomorrow.

replies.msg:
Our world nowadays has been heavily influenced by capitalism. We can hardly escape from advertisements in our daily lives. With time, we are gradually inculcated with the concept that we can only be happy through material possessions and social success. Therefore, I largely agree that people’s worth nowadays seems to mainly depend on their social status and material possessions, instead of the traditional values such as honour and kindness.

Whenever we make new friends or chat with our relatives in some annual gatherings, we will commonly be asked about our occupations, and will be judged whether we are successful or not according to our answers. People are not interested to know if you are a honorable or kind person, because they tend to judge you by your occupation which reflects your income level and social status. Understanding more about international affairs is often beneficial to one's perspective towards the current world. And many Hong Kongers, to be fair, lack global vision. Especially for OP who is going to graduate and enter the workforce.

Write about the following topic:

People attend colleges or universities for many different reasons (for example, new experiences, career preparation, increased knowledge etc.). Why do you think people attend colleges or universities?

You should give reasons for your answer using your own ideas and experience.

Write at least 250 words.

----------

Nowadays, more and more people tend to receive tertiary education instead of leaving schools after secondary education. The reasons why they prefer going to colleges or universities will be discussed in this essay.

First of all, many people tend to receive tertiary education because of career needs. Since our society has been evolving into a knowledge-based economy, a lot of jobs on the market require jobseekers to have tertiary education level. For example, high-paying professional jobs like doctors or lawyers require candidates to have at least a degree in their respective disciplines. In this connection, people are more eager to attend colleges or universities in order to enhance their competitiveness on the job market.

Second, some people have a great desire for knowledge, so they would like to continue their pursuit in the academic field in tertiary educational institutes. For example, a student who is intrigued in science may want to study physics, chemistry or other similar science subjects in the university.

Last but not least, we should not underestimate the effect of government’s promotion on tertiary education. In order to prepare the population for the knowledge-based economy, the government has been encouraging people to receive tertiary education through a number of measures, such as establishing more colleges and universities as well as providing financial support for the students who have difficulties in affording tuition. With relevant promotional policy implemented by the government, people are more eager to attend colleges or universities.

To conclude, I think people tend to receive tertiary education for different reasons. No matter what the reason is, I always think that going to colleges or universities is a wise choice because they are the places which help us to grow.

(284 words)

You should give reasons for your answer using your own ideas and experience.

Write at least 250 words.

----------

Nowadays, more and more people tend to receive tertiary education instead of leaving schools after secondary education. The reasons why they prefer going to colleges or universities will be discussed in this essay.

First of all, many people tend to receive tertiary education because of career needs. Since our society has been evolving into a knowledge-based economy, a lot of jobs on the market require jobseekers to have tertiary education level. For example, high-paying professional jobs like doctors or lawyers require candidates to have at least a degree in their respective disciplines. In this connection, people are more eager to attend colleges or universities in order to enhance their competitiveness on the job market.

Second, some people have a great desire for knowledge, so they would like to continue their pursuit in the academic field in tertiary educational institutes. For example, a student who is intrigued in science may want to study physics, chemistry or other similar science subjects in the university.

Last but not least, we should not underestimate the effect of government’s promotion on tertiary education. In order to prepare the population for the knowledge-based economy, the government has been encouraging people to receive tertiary education through a number of measures, such as establishing more colleges and universities as well as providing financial support for the students who have difficulties in affording tuition. With relevant promotional policy implemented by the government, people are more eager to attend colleges or universities.

To conclude, I think people tend to receive tertiary education for different reasons. No matter what the reason is, I always think that going to colleges or universities is a wise choice because they are the places which help us to grow.

(284 words)

Our world nowadays has been heavily influenced by capitalism. We can hardly escape from advertisements in our daily lives. With time, we are gradually inculcated with the concept that we can only be happy through material possessions and social success. Therefore, I largely agree that people’s worth nowadays seems to mainly depend on their social status and material possessions, instead of the traditional values such as honour and kindness.

Whenever we make new friends or chat with our relatives in some annual gatherings, we will commonly be asked about our occupations, and will be judged whether we are successful or not according to our answers. People are not interested to know if you are a honorable or kind person, because they tend to judge you by your occupation which reflects your income level and social status. If you tell someone that you have a professional job like a doctor or lawyer, they will immediately show admiration to you. On the contrary, if you tell someone that you have a blue-collar job, they will probably be not interested in you, or even look down on you.

While the above tendency is prevalent in Hong Kong, I will try to keep myself from being affected by it, because I think integrity, kindness and trust are important values which should not be ignored. I still believe that these traditional values can bring us true happiness. For example, you cannot build a close relationship without trust. My conclusion is that we should never desert the traditional values, and should learn to understand the importance of them. Otherwise, we will be drowned in the materialistic world where true happiness can never be found.

In my humble opinion, you should work on brevity.

As we live in the age of capitalism, commercial advertisements are literally omnipresent. We are inculcated with the value that materialism is the only way to happiness. I largely agree that social status and material possessions have unfortunately become the sole measurements of a person's worth.

Likewise, I think your second paragraph can be reorganised in a more economical way.

----------------------------

The graph provided in the question illustrates the rise of population of China and India since the year 2000, and the predicted population growth of the two countries until 2050.

According to the graph, both the two countries will have a population increase after the 50 year time frame, with the Chinese population growing from around 1.25 trillion to almost 1.4 trillion, and the Indian population rising sharply from 1 trillion to nearly 1.6 trillion.

While there will be population hike in both the two countries, I would like to point out that their courses of growth are different. For China, the population will rise to approximately 1.45 trillion in around 2030, then it will begin to drop and will end up at nearly 1.4 trillion. For India, the population growth rate will enjoy a significant increase throughout the whole time frame without any fluctuation. In other words, even China is used to have a higher population than India, it is predicted that this situation will be reversed in around 2030, and India will eventually surpass China in population.

Example:

The following charts represent the weight measurements of people living in Charlestown in 1955 and 2015. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.



--------------------------

The two charts provided in the question illustrate weight measurements of Charlestown’s inhabitants in 1955 and 2015 respectively. Relevant information is shown in percentage and divided into five age groups, namely 20-29, 30-39, 40-49, 50-59 and 60-69.

According to the chart for 1955, most inhabitants in all the five age groups had the ideal weight, while those aged between 20-29 and 60-69 years old were more prone to underweight. There was generally no overweight problem as only less than 20 percent of all inhabitants were overweight or obese; none of those aged from 20 to 39 years old were obese.

On the contrary, the chart for 2015 shows a much different situation. While most inhabitants in the age group of 20-29 could maintain their weight at the ideal level, there was a conspicuous trend that inhabitants easily became overweight or even obese as their ages increased, with the age group of 60-69 having the highest percentage of obesity which was approximately 60 percent; less than 4 percent of those aged from 30 to 59 were underweight.

較嚴謹嘅訓練方法：

Step 1: 跟IPA重新學番所有音（e.g. th都有兩種發音，然後逐個音嘅生字練
Step 2: 讀書/報紙，每句每隻字都試下唔同嘅高低音（intonation），目的係mit甩廣東話人嘅9音
Step 3: 練 stressing (將重點字眼分開+拉長黎讀，其他字黐埋+快讀

簡單啲： 開套英文電視劇，模仿啲人嘅發音、語速同語調）

The Ideological Idealism


When it comes to China, people immediately come up with closely packed skyscrapers standing in a well-developed city or the insane growth of GDP. Having studied the history and realized the increasing influence from China, I see China as an obscure term instead of a fast-growing economical entity. Is it a collection of culture and history? A geographical definition? Or a de facto regime?

The authority has been telling me the country has 5000 years of history and culture. Within this long period of time, languages, characters and dynasties changed again and again. Mongolians invaded China and built an empire where their culture was superior to any other, especially Chinese culture; Manchu people forced civilians to adopt their tradition and learn their language. No matter how the culture evolved and dynasties changed, they are all categorized into one umbrella term – China, which barely generalizes countless historical events.

The territory of China varied frequently throughout the history. During the Western Zhou dynasty, the territory was only as huge as a province of China nowadays. Furthermore, the Mongol empire in 13-14th centuries held lands much larger than twice of modern China, maintaining influence from Eastern Europe, India to Sea of Japan. In some cases, like the Five dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period, the territory split into numerous nations. There are too many geographical versions of China to study when you read any Chinese history textbook. Maybe it is not the best way to describe the incidents in this specific location.

Let’s say the People’s Republic of China is the regime of China. Established in 1949, the history of China is only 69 years. It basically contradicts that China has 5000 years of history. Rewind the tape a bit more and take a look at the so-called dynasties. They were in fact different regimes, ruled by different emperors and race. Classifying Mongolians, Jurchen, Manchu as well as other race being viewed as ethnic minorities nowadays in China, is to undermine their influence on mankind’s history, or making an even more extreme accusation, very nationalist.

Historians have spent their best efforts to offer a whole picture for human beings and they definitely deserve the credit. But one should bear in mind that victors always determine the history, especially the totalitarian ones.

用
學咁多唔撚用都係冇用

replies.msg:
When we talk about China, we immediately come up with an image of dense skyscrapers standing in a well-developed city or a graph of exponential growth of GDP. After studying the history of China, I view China as an obscure term instead of a solid fast-growing economical entity. Is China a collection of culture and history? A geographical definition? Or a de facto regime?

The authority claimed the country has 5000 years of history and culture. Dialects, language characters and dynasties changed rapidly. Mongolians invaded China and built an empire where their culture was superior to any other, especially Chinese culture(唔知up咩); Manchu people forced Han civilians to adopt their traditions and learn their language, Mandarin. No matter how the culture evolved and dynasties changed, they are all categorized into one umbrella term – China, which barely generalizes countless historical events(唔知up咩).

The territory of China varied frequently throughout the history. During the Western Zhou dynasty, the territory was only as huge as a province of China nowadays. Furthermore(可省略), the Mongol empire(claims to be a part of orthodox Chinese history) in 13-14th centuries held lands much larger than twice of modern China, spreading influence from Eastern Europe, India to Sea of Japan. In some cases, like the Five dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period, the “China territory” split into numerous nations. Map of China changed a lot and it may not be the best way to define China and its history by geographical location.(唔知係咪你意思)

Let’s say the People’s Republic of China (PRC), established in 1949, is the regime of China. Under this definition, it basically contradicts that China has 5000 years of history. How about the past “dynasties” of China? They were in fact different regimes ruled by different emperors and races. The former ruling class, Mongolians, Jurchen, Manchu as well as other races are classifying as ethnic minorities in modern Han-ruled China. This classification maybe is to undermine their influence on mankind’s history, or

making an even more extreme accusation, very nationalist.(呢句又口語, 意思文法都錯哂)

Historians try their best to tell the truth, but history is written by the victors.

幫你重寫過, 睇下點

大約明你意思, 但有D眼高手低, 表達唔到自己意見, 就鳩寫.
至少唔係鳩用好多深字, 睇得好舒服. 如果識多D生字, 描述得再到位就最好啦
係有D文法問題&有D累積. 學下寫得精簡D啦. 睇下The Economist, 學下點樣寫簡而有力,有內容有意思文章
第一段有D扮野, 用好多adj. 但其實係有D柒, 太多了, 仲要下文D文風不夾
